fields.headline: A view to a killing: how Amazon will exploit Bond and other MGM classics
fields.standfirst: The pay-TV giant has the chance to turn popular films into ‚Äòuniverses‚Äô of stories ‚Äì and steal a march in the content-hungry streaming wars
fields.trailText: The pay-TV giant has the chance to turn popular films into ‚Äòuniverses‚Äô of stories ‚Äì and steal a march in the content-hungry streaming wars
fields.body:
Amazon‚Äôs $8.5bn deal to buy MGM, the Hollywood studio behind James Bond, The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale and Gone With the Wind, has secured it the rights to a century‚Äôs worth of TV and film titles that the streaming giant intends to exploit with a wave of remakes, reimaginings and spin-offs.

The deal to buy the 97-year-old Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which has an immense library of 4,000 film titles and 17,000 hours of TV programming, is designed to supercharge Amazon‚Äôs content pipeline, which is the lifeblood of any competitor in the global battle for streaming supremacy.

As the streaming wars have intensified, new entrants ‚Äì such as Disney+, Sky, Comcast‚Äôs Peacock, and WarnerMedia‚Äôs HBO Max ‚Äì are increasingly refusing to license their own crown-jewel shows and films to rivals, in order to fuel their own streaming services.

Amazon has not pursued an original-content strategy in the heavyweight way that Netflix has. Just 3% of its 41,000 hours of TV shows and films are originals or owned content, compared with a fifth of the 39,000-hour library at Netflix, according to Ampere Analysis.

The greatest opportunity is with the Bond franchise. There is a huge amount of intellectual property that has not been exploited

John Mass, Content Partners

‚ÄúIt is getting harder to get library content ‚Äì they‚Äôre not going to get shows like Friends now, they‚Äôre locked in elsewhere,‚Äù says Michael Pachter, a media analyst at Wedbush. ‚ÄúTo create 4,000 movies would take them 200 years. To create 17,000 hours of TV would take an eternity. They couldn‚Äôt do it fast enough. They had to buy something. The question is how much Amazon can now exploit.‚Äù

Much of the focus has been on MGM‚Äôs flagship property: James Bond. At 59 years old, the evergreen screen spy is the world‚Äôs second-longest running film franchise after Godzilla, and some analysts have estimated he could be worth half the near-$9bn price tag of the whole library.

Bond is a treasure trove, unexploited beyond the 25 feature films focusing on its star, which Amazon would dearly love to develop into a Marvel- or Star Wars-like ‚Äúuniverse‚Äù. The only problem is that Bond is partly owned by Eon Productions in the UK, which is run by Barbara Broccoli and Michael G Wilson, who exercise strict control over how the character is used ‚Äì even down to choosing the actor who plays him. Following the announcement of the deal, they reiterated that 007‚Äôs primary home would remain the big screen, saying: ‚ÄúWe are committed to continue making James Bond films for the worldwide theatrical audience.‚Äù

Plans for one potential spin-off in 2002 ‚Äì a movie based on the character Jinx, played by Halle Berry in Die Another Day ‚Äì were scrapped the following year, while the highly successful Young Bond series of books for young adults has never made it beyond print.

‚ÄúI think the greatest opportunity is with the Bond franchise,‚Äù says John Mass at Content Partners, a Los Angeles-based investment firm that owns the rights to content including Black Hawk Down, Olympus Has Fallen and part of the CSI television franchise. ‚ÄúI think that ‚Äòuniverse‚Äô is probably an overused term, but I do think that there is a huge amount of intellectual property that has not been exploited. What Bond has demonstrated is that the asset, the brand, is resilient.‚Äù

Still, beyond Bond, MGM ‚Äì which made $1.5bn (¬£1bn) last year, mostly from licensing its properties ‚Äì has an array of valuable assets ripe for further exploitation. Rocky has been given a new lease of life with the Creed series of films starring Michael B Jordan. A second Addams Family animated film is due for release this year, while a TV series is in the works at Netflix. Disney+ has an upcoming series, Willow, based on the 1988 Ron Howard film, and a hybrid animated/live-action reboot of The Pink Panther is in the works.

Meanwhile, the Russo brothers ‚Äì the directors of one of the biggest-grossing film of all time, Avengers: Endgame ‚Äì are on board to remake several films, starting with The Thomas Crown Affair; a third instalment of Legally Blonde is due next year; and CBS has psychological crime drama Clarice, a TV spin-off which has its roots in The Silence of the Lambs.

But unlike MGM, which was forced into bankruptcy a decade ago and currently carries about $2bn in debt, Amazon has the financial firepower to supercharge the exploitation of this library. The company, which has $73bn in cash on hand and a market value of $1.6 trillion, spent $11bn on content last year and will lay out $15.5bn this year. It has reportedly spent $465m on its first TV series set in the world of Lord of the Rings, the rights for which were secured after Amazon‚Äôs founder, Jeff Bezos, reportedly told executives to ‚Äúfind a Game of Thrones‚Äù to take the fight to Netflix, the world‚Äôs leading streamer.

Observers and analysts speculate at possibilities including a remake of Thelma and Louise, which celebrates its 30th anniversary this year, or reviving the late-80s series Thirtysomething. Franchises including Stargate and Tomb Raider appear ripe for a major new investment, while RoboCop is ready for new audiences following 2014‚Äôs disappointing remake. TV hits The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale and Fargo are currently locked in deals with Hulu and FX, but are also viewed as ripe for future exploitation.

The only content off the table is some 2,000 classic films, including hits such as Gone with the Wind, The Wizard of Oz and Singin‚Äô in the Rain, which MGM sold to Warner Bros in 1986.

‚ÄúIn terms of production there is a lot of intellectual property that is under-exploited from a rights standpoint,‚Äù says Mass. ‚ÄúThere are loads of potential sequels, remakes and prequels in the MGM library. I‚Äôm sure MGM have done a good job with it, but the streaming wars are going on, and a new team of people at Amazon will uncover a lot more opportunities.‚Äù

fields.headline: ‚ÄòDamned bastards - I‚Äôm still alive‚Äô: Gomorrah author hails court victory over mafia threats
fields.standfirst: Roberto Saviano says that a court has shown that the crime clans ‚Äì whose threats forced him to live with a bodyguard ‚Äì are not invincible
fields.trailText: Roberto Saviano says that a court has shown that the crime clans ‚Äì whose threats forced him to live with a bodyguard ‚Äì are not invincible
fields.body:
The internationally renowned anti-mafia writer Roberto Saviano has declared that ‚Äújournalism has been vindicated; words are vindicated ‚Äì and so am I‚Äù, after a landmark judgment in Rome over threats to his life.

Judges ruled on Monday that a courtroom manoeuvre 13 years ago by a Camorra mafia boss and his lawyer constituted a threat to Saviano‚Äôs life, and that of a colleague ‚Äì Rosaria Capacchione, then of the Naples daily Il Mattino ‚Äì condemning the journalists to live ever since in the shadows, under bodyguard.

‚ÄúMy life does not greatly change,‚Äù Saviano told the Observer after the verdict. ‚ÄúI will still need to keep my bodyguard. And of course, the ruling does not give me back those 13 years, forced to live a hidden half-life, constantly vigilant, under guard, for all that time.

‚ÄúBut the ruling does show that the mafia is not invincible, that it cannot threaten journalists without sanction, and that the clans are afraid of the word, of journalism.‚Äù

After an oft-delayed 13-year trial, Rome‚Äôs criminal court found Francesco Bidognetti, chief enforcer of the Casalesi clan of the Naples region mafia, and his lawyer, Michele Santonastaso, guilty of threatening the journalists‚Äô lives by filing a document into the ‚ÄúSpartacus‚Äù maxi-trial. It ended after 12 years in 2010, with 16 Camorra bosses, including Bidognetti, jailed for life.

Bidognetti was a senior, crucial figure in a regime of murder, extortion and terror around the Casalesi base of Casal di Principe, north of Naples, and mastermind of its corrupt control over multimillion-euro businesses of waste management ‚Äì much of it toxic ‚Äì across the Campania region.

The document at stake was apparently a matter of legal procedure, entered into the maxi-trial shortly before the appeal hearing ended in March 2008. It requested a suspension of the entire trial, and that it be referred from Naples to another jurisdiction, because of the influence that Saviano and Capacchione were said to ‚Äúwield over the judges with their writing‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe mafia does not make its threats directly,‚Äù explains Saviano. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt issue a fatwa like Iran or Isis. Mafia semantics are complex and coded, and their menaces are made at a diagonal.‚Äù

He cites a famous foreboding made by Cosa Nostra boss Michele ‚Äì Il Papa (the Pope) ‚Äì Greco during the Sicilian maxi-trial of the 1980s: ‚ÄúGreco said to the court: ‚ÄòWe wish your justice to be serene, and that this serenity will accompany you throughout your life.‚Äô It sounds like a blessing, but it wasn‚Äôt, it was a threat [to jurors and prosecutors],‚Äù says Saviano.

‚ÄúAnd with this manoeuvre in 2008,‚Äù he explains, ‚ÄúBidognetti was saying that if he and his fellow mafiosi were convicted in that court, Rosaria and I would be complicit. And that if the mafiosi were acquitted, they would regard us ‚Äì Rosaria reporting at local level, me nationally ‚Äì as part of the attempt to prosecute them.

‚ÄúThis threat was, and still is, unique in criminal history. It labelled us as enemies of the defendants, whose work as journalists had urged the state into action against them. According to them, it was I who was a menace to the course of justice in Naples, not them, the killers awaiting judgment.‚Äù

The threat was made in an atmosphere of extreme menace: while the maxi-trial called more than 500 witnesses, and handed down more than 700 years of jail terms, five people involved in the case were murdered.

The maxi-trial had coincided with publication in 2006 of Saviano‚Äôs bestselling book Gomorrah, which revealed the Camorra‚Äôs operations and had infuriated the mafia. Saviano was put under guard, and this was augmented after the 2008 legal manoeuvre; both the clans and the journalists knew exactly what it meant. ‚ÄúIt was coded, but clear,‚Äù says Saviano.

Capacchione, who served as a deputy for Italy‚Äôs Democratic party from 2013 to 2018, told the Ansa news agency last week: ‚ÄúThey were real death threats against us.‚Äù

Last week‚Äôs judgment in Rome seals Saviano‚Äôs and Capacchione‚Äôs argument as legal fact, ruling the content of the referral request to be a threat and crime.

Bidognetti, who is serving several life sentences, was given 18 months for threatening the journalists, and Santonastaso, who has a previous conviction for aiding and abetting the mafia, 14 months. The judges have 90 days to publish their reasoning.

‚ÄúThey are token sentences,‚Äù says Saviano, ‚Äúbut so important in establishing what has caused me to live the life I have lived, and lost: constantly surveilled, hunted, watched, under protection, and wondering what life I would be living had these threats not been issued.‚Äù

He adds: ‚ÄúThis has taken 13 years for us to prove this. Thirteen years of living like this. It‚Äôs hard for an Anglo-Saxon public to understand how long these trials can take.‚Äù Delays in the process are due to adjournments and debates over jurisdiction.

The threat and judgment, says Saviano, ‚Äúalso demonstrate how the mafia, with this court manoeuvre, regards the perimeters of journalism, and the implied instruction that a journalist ‚Äòdo a good job‚Äô so far as they are concerned. They know this is a democracy, that there will be an article about a murder or an arrest, but that‚Äôs the limit. Then they come into court and say what they always say: everything happens, but we didn‚Äôt do it. Cosa Nostra exists, but we do not exist. And they expect us to report that.

‚ÄúBut what does it mean to go beyond the limit? What if a journalist investigates the facts in relation to one another, and draws up a map of the mafia‚Äôs economic interests and institutional and political relations? Then, one crosses the line, exceeds the limit.‚Äù

Writing in Corriere della Sera last week, Saviano paid tribute to Capacchione ‚Äì ‚Äúwho has dedicated a large part of her life to reporting on the Casalesi clan with courage and determination‚Äù ‚Äì his lawyers and media colleagues who had brought and followed the proceedings throughout.

Related: Why the mafia are taking care of everyone's business

Saviano calculates: ‚ÄúWhy would Bidognetti, already serving several life sentences, spend 13 years defending himself against this charge of making a threat against me? It‚Äôs because so long as I live, his threat has failed. Therefore he has to pretend he didn‚Äôt issue it. So long as I live, he loses kudos; he loses credibility in the eyes of his mates and rivals.

‚ÄúBidognetti threatened Saviano, and Saviano still lives,‚Äù reflects the writer. ‚ÄúIn the eyes of my enemies, my most egregious fault is that I am still alive. This week is a victory for the power of the word, not mine or even Rosaria‚Äôs. But when I walked out of that courtroom on Monday, I did think ‚Äì as I wrote in the final line of Gomorrah ‚Äì damned bastards, I‚Äôm still alive.‚Äù

results.webTitle: Cinema chains count on 007 to restore their Covid-hit takings

fields.headline: Cinema chains count on 007 to restore their Covid-hit takings
fields.standfirst: Hopes are high for the September release of the latest in the super-spy franchise, No Time to Die
fields.trailText: Hopes are high for the September release of the latest in the super-spy franchise, No Time to Die
fields.body:
As ticket sales flicker back into life following the reopening of cinemas earlier this month, theatre owners are banking on one film to deliver them pre-pandemic-level crowds and box office success: Bond.

Sticking to its roadmap out of lockdown, the government allowed cinemas to reopen from 17 May. This gave Hollywood studios confidence in being able to turn a profit by returning to the big screen with blockbusters such as Marvel‚Äôs Black Widow and the latest in the Fast and Furious franchise this summer.

But after three pandemic-enforced date changes, the biggest film of the year could be No Time to Die, the final outing of Daniel Craig as superspy 007. It is regarded by many in the cinema industry as unofficially marking the end of the health crisis that has devastated their finances.

Advertiser demand for the film is enormous ‚Äì more so now it is back in its pre-Christmas slot, which advertisers like

Clare Turner, Pearl & Dean

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got Bond,‚Äù says Tim Richards, chief executive at Vue, the UK‚Äôs third-largest cinema chain. ‚ÄúIt has been delayed because it is so good. The confidence that everyone has in that movie, the pent-up demand ‚Ä¶ It is going to be very good. Whenever I get asked for a movie release date from any of our customers, it is usually related to Bond.‚Äù

The Bond franchise, owned by Eon Productions and MGM‚Äôs new parent, Amazon, is carefully geared towards maximising box office sales. There have only been 25 films in 59 years and spin-offs are taboo, which makes Bond a premium big-screen draw. The last film, Spectre, made $880m globally, while predecessor Skyfall topped $1.1bn. The promise of such returns was the reason a $600m offer from Apple for a digital release during lockdown was ultimately rejected in favour of waiting until cinemas could deliver.

Pearl & Dean, which sells advertising for about a fifth of the UK cinema market, believes the hype is such that ad bookings will be back at 2019 levels when Bond premieres at the end of September.

‚ÄúWe have got a Bond,‚Äù says Clare Turner, sales director at Pearl & Dean. ‚ÄúEvery single time, pre-Covid, screen slots for Bond were fully sold out. fields.headline: Jim Snidero: Live at the Deer Head Inn review ‚Äì a glorious sense of swing
fields.standfirst:
(Savant)
Snidero and band take comfort music to the next level in this hugely enjoyable, at times mind-boggling set recorded last year
fields.trailText: Snidero and band take comfort music to the next level
fields.body:
Believe it or not, this was recorded last October ‚Äì live, before an audience (small and wearing masks) at a jazz club in rural Pennsylvania. Jim Snidero, an alto saxophonist I admire for the deceptively easy grace of his style, had not played in public for about seven months, and neither had the other members of his quartet. They play brilliantly here, especially Snidero and pianist Orrin Evans, although the whole performance is, not surprisingly, a bit more intense than usual.

The programme consists of eight familiar standards: ‚Äúcomfort music‚Äù, according to Snidero. It brings out his perfect taste with ballads, never overdoing the decoration on My Old Flame, and releases the whole band‚Äôs glorious sense of swing in faster numbers. Bassist Peter Washington and drummer Joe Farnsworth maintain a kind of springy balance that lifts the music so that it seems almost to be floating. I found following Snidero‚Äôs sinuous progress through the harmonic outskirts of Bye Bye Blackbird mind-boggling and, at the same time, hugely enjoyable. It‚Äôs easy to forget how exciting straight-ahead jazz improvisation on old songs can be, until something like this turns up unexpectedly.
